prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: A party who receives notice of a motion to transfer by a party or a conditional transfer order by the Panel must respond within 21 days to the motion or order. The Panel Rules provide that failure to respond within that period will result in the Panel deeming the party to acquiesce in the motion or order.[1] The Panel has readily enforced this provision.[2] Panel decisions regularly issues decisions that discuss the views of the “responding parties;” the view of others are implicitly ignored.

A party seeking to oppose transfer should serve an appropriate response on the parties and file it with the Panel. Any response is limited to 20 pages.[3] The failure to serve and file such a response is not fatal, however. The Panel reviews even uncontested motions on their merits, and may overrule objections to transfer even if there is no opposition to those objections. In one case the court ordered transfer of a tag-along action on a conditional transfer order despite the fact that one of the parties to the tag-along action filed objections to transfer that were not opposed by any other party.[4] Nonetheless, it is prudent not to rely on the Panel to discover the reasons any motion should not be granted. If there are objections to any proposed action of the Panel, they should be stated in writing and served and filed.

The Panel Rules no longer expressly require a response to the averments of a motion for transfer (or any other motion) to be in separately numbered paragraphs, with the numbering corresponding to the motion to which it responds, nor that averments be:
Admitted in part and denied in part.
Nonetheless, that traditional format is an effective way to present a party's opposition. Motions and responses before the Panel are formal, taking on the form of pleadings.[5]

There is one response to motion to transfer that is not authorized and not at all helpful to the processing of the cases by the Panel—a “counter” motion to transfer. Once a motion to transfer is filed all other parties in litigation should file a response, not their own motion for transfer. The party first moving for transfer does not have any procedural or tactical advantage over other parties, other than having invoked the Panel's attention to the litigation. If another party agrees that transfer is appropriate, but opposes transfer to the district suggested by the moving party, that can be handled in a response that says just that: joining in the request for transfer but alleging that transfer should be made to the alternative district of , for whatever reasons are appropriate. With respect to the question of selection of the transferee district in this situation, both the movant and the responding party urging transfer to a different district stand with equal footing before the Panel—the movant does not have any right of priority or superiority by virtue of having filed first.

If a party erroneously files a second motion for transfer, it will either be rejected by the Clerk or it will be converted into (deemed, essentially) a response to the initial motion. This will in any event delay the consideration of the party's position and create additional work for the Panel. It is a “rookie mistake” that should not be made. The Panel rules now expressly provide that any other pleading filed after a motion for transfer is filed will be treated as a response to the initial motion, so it is still a rookie mistake, but the consequences may be less dire.[6]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See J.P.M.L. R. 6.1(c). The Panel rules are reproduced in § 4:34.

See, e.g., In re Sinking of the Motor Vessel Ukola, 462 F. Supp. 385 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Air Crash Disaster in Ionian Sea on September 8, 1974, 407 F. Supp. 238, 240 n.1 (J.P.M.L. 1974) (reported as 1974).
See In re Air Crash Disaster at Tweed-New Haven on June 7, 1971, 368 F. Supp. 815, 816 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Sample motions and responses are contained in Appendix A.
